body: $ZIM You will find a link here to submit a complaint about your broker to the NYSE: https://www.nyse.com/regulation/complaints-and-inquiries

According to the NYSE due-bills only apply to shares that were sold before the ex-div date. They exist so that the dividend may be passed to the new buyer. If your broker uses due-bills as an excuse for not paying you
created_at: they are being dishonest and probably don't want to give the true explanation (which might be that they loaned your shares out and have to wait for a short seller to pony up the dividend.

$ZIM For "investors" looking for a long-term growth company that is a market disruptor
created_at: this could be the company. $ZIM has solid operating metrics.  Once their transition happens expect the numbers to grow with solid divs.  To be realistic the stock in 2023 will probably be in the $12-14 range at the current P/E but if they are valued fairly $ZIM would grow to $20-$30 range at a typical P/E of 2-3 like other shipping companies.  This company has better metrics than most other shippers but without the heavy burden of debt and assets.  They can react quicker and since they don't have heavy ownership in vessels & they can limit losses on shipping and can more easily take advantage of more profitable routes and markets.  For me
column3: this is a long-term play.  I am personally upsidedown on the stock price because I initially jumped at the div last year
column4: however I see value long terms.  Go read $ZIM guidance reports and be realistic.   2/2

body: $ZIM Market (including shorts) are reacting to the guidance given by $ZIM.   $ZIM says they are going from $6.1Bn Adj EBIT to $100-$500 Mn in Adj-EBIT for 2023.  Huge drop.  Even with the increased shipping rates
created_at: that is an increase from a lower rate but nowhere close to all-time highs that drove 2021 and 2022 results. The shorts see a big juicy profit to be made off a stock that will have lower near-term prospects.  $ZIM is clearly changing its business model from an asset-heavy model to an asset-light
column4: and nimble organization.  They will be able to react better to market changes through their ability to stop
column5: limit or add leases according to the market.  This
column7: is a new/young company.  They have been around since 1945 but this business model is less than 4 years old.  This shift will take a few years to entrench but then will continually improve over time.  For those that are in it just for the div it will be a tough year in 2023.  1/2

$ZIM
Are you seeking a global value and income stock?

The shipping industry has business risk: if a country and it's Docks and ship channels go into lock down. This creates a short collapse period followed by a spike. It occurred with COVID 19. Container prices jumped due to this event. There is currently a price contraction period for dry ship containers. It explains much of the Zim price swing from $71.40 to $16.

Zim has a PE ratio of .45. This is an extreme value stock. The market cap is $2.317 billion. Zim has weekly options. These frequently are not worth selling around the ex-dividend date. The stock is great without option income during those times.
ZIM Shipping is an Israeli transportation sector stock paying 72% annual dividends. 25% of the dividend is paid to Israel. It results in a net dividend of 54%
created_at: excluding your sovereign annual income tax. The resulting income is attractive and will hold up for the upcoming year. The Israeli tax is paid on Roth or 401K.
